awd_titl_txt: The Connection Between Sentiments and Social Status
awd_abstract_narration:
This project tests, by means of laboratory experiments, a new theory of how sentiments are related to social status in humans.  One strand of theory in group processes research has concerned how sentiments, the liking and disliking relations among group members, organize groups.  Another strand has concerned how the arrangement of social statuses in a task group fosters or hinders group members' opportunities to contribute to their group's goals.   The theory tested in this project is a combination of these.  Its potential benefits lie in its direct applicability to project teams within businesses, academia, and other professional organizations.

The theoretical predictions are derived using the mathematical apparatus of expectations states theory in the group processes tradition.  These predictions are tested using an experimental design involving six conditions.  The experimental set-up is an adaptation to three-person groups of the usual experimental configuration in this tradition in which social influence is measured by looking at change in a binary choice task.  For the entire study, valid data will be collected from 150 research participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Scholars have found that groups working to solve problems, who also need all group members to be engaged, are rife with social evaluation. That is, group members look to each other to judge which members have the competence to lead the informal group discussions necessary to complete the task. Those individuals who are perceived to have the most competence are typically looked upon by group members to put forth the best suggestions to get the job done.

Human beings do not have a sign on them that presents their level of competence for other group members to ascertain. Accordingly, group members look to visual and other social cues that connote individuals’ assumed levels of competence. Herein lies the issue: stereotypes about competence are part of our cultural experience (and this is NOT just with individuals from the US – this is true of most, if not all, societies). As such, humans tend to judge competence based on the cues that have stereotypes associated with them. This is often done not in a conscious way, but rather done by what social psychologists call “non-conscious processing” – these perceptions are arrived at by out-of-awareness hunches. Unfortunately, those who are disadvantaged by cultural stereotypes are often perceived as having less competence than those who are not disadvantaged. During conversations within task groups, a hierarchy forms (what is called a “status hierarchy”) that all group members non-advertently accept. Those who are perceived as having more competence are given more opportunities to perform at solving the group task, have task contributions that are evaluated more positively, and have more influence to steer the task, than do those perceived as having less competence.

What is important to remember is that perceptions are often not objective reality – those perceived to be the most competent may not actually be the most competent group members. And, the more successful task groups will be those whose group members correctly evaluate who should be leading the task, not necessarily those who are perceived to be competent based on cultural stereotypes.

Status characteristics theory is a formal theory that describes the detailed, basic process of how group members evaluate social cues and cultural stereotypes to form status hierarchies. Researchers who have developed this theory have also developed an experimental research design, called the standardized experimental setting, used to test which social cues enact the process by which status hierarchies are formed.

The current study was done to build on this well-regarded theory and its concomitant research design. One issue with the theory and the experimental design is that both were constructed by modeling two-person groups (dyads). This project aimed to extend status characteristics theory to include three person groups. This required data collection from three person groups within an updated computer protocol for the standardized experimental setting (valid N=150 subjects). These innovations are a quantum leap forward for our understanding of how status hierarchies emerge within task groups. Finally, an element of interaction that was thought to require a three-person configuration to convey disparate levels of competence should be tested with the new standardized experimental setting. Hence, we chose sentiments, how group members like or dislike one another, as that element.

Sentiments are interesting in that tests have shown that they do not enact status hierarchies within two person groups. However, if an interactant B understood that they would like interactant A and would dislike interactant C, sentiments may convey levels of competence, such that the liked individual is more competent than the disliked person. We collected the data for this type of task group interaction to determine if our predictions are correct – that, in fact, sentiments do have value for enacting status hierarchies in groups of three who are completing a collective task.

It should be noted that just because one dislikes someone does not mean that this person has lower levels of competence; similarly, just because someone likes someone does not mean that the target individual has higher levels of competence. This is how stereotypes are insidious – even our judgments about who is likable and who is unlikeable are based on stereotypes, and so evaluating likability as competence can be problematic. Sentiments should not bias group members’ understanding of capacities to complete tasks successfully.

Results of our study will show how status hierarchies are formed in more types of groups than are currently included within the scope of status characteristics theory. Evaluation of group members’ potential contribution to the task may be essential to completing the task. However, these evaluations should be done without the biases of cultural stereotypes. Knowing how stereotypes interfere with group members’ social evaluations and create status hierarchies will allow researchers to craft efficacious intervention strategies to ameliorate the process so that all group members have better opportunities to contribute.
